text: ah hi everyone it's anthony time tano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
chat pile album god's country this is
the debut full-length lp from oklahoma
noise rock and sludge metal outfit chat
pile yes this is their first lp but they
have been turning heads for a few years
now as they had a couple of really great
and promising eps that dropped back in
2019 pretty sure one of them ended up on
my eps of the year list and it's been so
long since those dropped i actually
forgot the band was still active until i
began to hear teasers to this new lp
which as i've dived into it has turned
out to be one of the most intense and
harrowing loud rock albums of the year
and what's funny is that it doesn't do
anything too crazy or complicated to
make that happen part of this record's
power is is really in its simplicity and
with that simplicity it achieves
greatness among these nine completely
crushing and harrowing tracks and
there's a fair amount of variety among
these songs too whether you're talking
about the monstrous and growling bass
lines on the opening track
slaughterhouse which are paired with
these sinister horror movie guitars
pounding and primal drums as well
there's all the obliteratingly heavy
rift passages all over the song why the
eerie and cavernous post punk guitars on
pamela the whirlwind of deafening noise
rock riffs that level everything in
their path on tropical beach
incorporated as well as wicked puppet
dance don't care if i burn is one of the
sickest and uh most
unsettling spoken word pieces that i
think i've heard in a while the tone of
this one as well is absolutely not
expected especially given just how
visceral and cathartic everything else
on the record is which is why it sticks
out so much but i think chatpile proves
on this one just because it's quiet
doesn't mean it's not depraved also
watch out for the blood curdling scream
in the second half on this one finally
there is the nine minute closer grimace
smokingweed.jpg which yes like many
other tracks here has loads of rumbling
riffs but this song really for me comes
down to its theatrical performance of
course that comes through on the vocal
and lyrical side but i'll get into that
in a minute there's also the production
that i would like to compliment on this
one too the riffs and bass tones all
over this thing are so goddamn thick
very rough and coarse as well it feels
like getting hit with a three ton cinder
block the vibe of this record sonically
reminds me of groups like uh the jesus
lizard or god flesh a little bit
lots of steve albini related projects to
big black shellac the drums as i
mentioned earlier are so punchy
hard-hitting and clear and much of the
time the vocals and lead guitars have a
very nice placement and eq in the mix as
well the performances across this record
are very raw and very organic whole
thing feels like you're listening to the
band perform this live either in an
abandoned warehouse or a factory floor
now let me dive into the vocals a little
bit which are just as blunt and as
straightforward as everything else here
but in my opinion they really are like
the selling point of the record the
crown jewel of the lp as they are so
deranged and manic and out of control to
the point where the psychotically
suicidal episode depicted on the closing
track is so intense and so real uh it's
a little difficult to sit through the
opener slaughterhouse is nearly as
horrifying but for different reasons the
shrill howls of hammers and grease send
a chill up my spine plus all the lyrical
descriptions of the removal of skin or
wearing a different skin but for all the
madness portrayed on many of these
tracks there's a lot of clarity on this
lp too whether you're talking about the
lyrics that dive a bit into capitalist
greed on tropical beaches incorporated
or the song y which i think tackles one
of the greatest horrors of our modern
society and that is homelessness and
illustrates that homelessness is this
really ugly thing that we are just made
to accept as normal something that can't
be helped and if we see someone who is
homeless it is most definitely due to a
personal or moral failing of some sort
this preposterous presumption is
attacked with simply the question of why
why do people have to live outside we
have the means and the resources to
change that as a society if we wanted to
and yet we don't plus i love that this
is the topical focus for the song within
the entirety of its run time usually
when issues like this are being
addressed in a track this will come up
and then we'll sort of jump onto
something else but no for chat pile and
rightfully so this is something that is
worth focusing intensely on and
singularly on at least for the duration
of the song with the track pamela the
vocals are a bit more buried and
under-delivered than i would have liked
especially during the passages where the
guitars get quite heavy but still this
song serves as a kind of creepy breather
that adds to the overall flow of the
record the mutant growls and grunts all
over wicked puppet dance are a treat as
well with the freaking echo making it
kind of call out into the abyss and some
of the more guttural vocal passages have
almost a death metal tone to them too
some of the plotting and mid-paced
riffing on the song anywhere does get a
little tedious after a while still some
of the sickest guitar work and vocal
passages come through in the first half
of this track and generally i see this
song as a pretty smart execution of some
very obvious slint influence the mask
also features some of the most menacing
screams on this record throughout plus
those refrains of line up the animals
it's all quite a shock to the system in
an extreme sense which is a great
contrast to the following track that i
mentioned earlier i don't care if i burn
which is just as hard and intense
emotionally uh but delivered in a
completely different way now this whole
record emotionally and vocally does come
to a peak on the closing track that i
mentioned earlier the play by playing
back and forth on this one emotionally
and narratively between the unhinged
screams and just the constant uh
combating just the fighting off of these
uh
very dark and very disturbing thoughts
yeah it is genuinely twisted and uh kind
of triggering i imagine uh for people
who have had uh similar feelings similar
experiences may have to warn some of you
guys on this one because it really truly
is a lot like it barely even feels like
a performance in any way whatsoever it
sounds like somebody is having some kind
of like mental breakdown but just like
riffs are going on in the background i
suppose in that sense there is a raw
intensity to
the singing on this lp that isn't too
unlike a project like suicide for
example obviously chat pile inhabits
totally different genres of music but
there is something kind of similar there
there is overlap there in terms of
something incredibly dark and um
just really frightening being tapped
into overall i really loved this lp
there were a few tracks that had
passages that sort of lulled for me on
top of it it does feel like a debut in
that
the band comes off as still kind of you
know learning what their sound and style
entirely is really still in this like
semi-incubation and explorative phase
where they could potentially grow into
more sounds and more versatility in the
future fingers crossed i hope so because
that would really only improve their
sound and the flow of future records but
with that being said as this currently
is it's fantastic it's amazing it is
pummeling it is quite a ride and one
that i would highly recommend so long as
you're not too faint of heart or
anything uh feeling a strong eight on
this one transition have you given this
record a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should i
review next hit the like if you like
please subscribe and please don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
chatpile
forever
